PMoV2 was encapsulated in four MOFs (MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) with different cavity sizes and window sizes using a hydrothermal synthesis method. Then, a layer of mesoporous silica was coated on the surface of the MOFs to obtain four designed three-layer encapsulated catalysts 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized through various characterization methods, and the influence of different MOF window sizes of the four catalysts on the removal rate of four thiophene sulfides was investigated. The optimal reaction conditions were also explored for the optimal catalyst. The results indicate that under simulated fuel of 2400 ppm, 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 owns the highest catalytic activity. Under optimal conditions, the total removal rate of four thiophene compounds was 91.52 %, and after ten cycles, the efficiency could still reach 86.24 %. This is attributed to the sufficient cavity size of UiO-67, which provides assurance for the loading of PMoV2 and the large window size, making it possible for the smooth reaction between sulfides and PMoV2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 Oxidative desulfurization Three-layer coated catalyst Data availability The data that support the findings of this study are all provided in the manuscript. 1 Introduction Energy is an important material foundation for human survival and development, and 80 % of the world's energy comes from fossil fuels. Before the emergence of reliable new energy sources, fossil fuels still remain the main energy source for the future [1]. However, fossil fuels contain a large amount of sulfur-containing compounds, which are converted into SOx and sulfur-containing solid particles after combustion. Emissions into the air not only endanger human health, but also react with O2 and H2O in the air to form acid rain, causing serious environmental pollution [2,3]. Therefore, multiple countries around the world have established strict standards for sulfur content in fuel, requiring a maximum sulfur limit of 10 ppm for gasoline and diesel. Therefore, the development of deep desulfurization technology is urgent [4]. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is the process of using catalysts to hydrogenate the C-S bonds of sulfides in fuel, which are then converted into hydrogen sulfide and hydrocarbons. The hydrogen sulfide is then removed through gas-liquid separation or adsorption to achieve desulfurization [5,6]. HDS technology has a good effect on the removal of aliphatic sulfides (such as thiols, sulfides.), but it is not conducive to the removal of thiophene compounds (benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene, etc.), which is related to their aromaticity and spatial hindrance [7–9]. Adsorption desulfurization (ADS) is a process that utilizes the interaction between adsorbents and sulfide molecules to remove sulfides from the oil phase and enter the adsorbent phase through chemical or physical adsorption, thereby achieving fuel desulfurization [10]. ADS technology has the advantages of mild reaction conditions, simple operation, and minimal impact on the octane number of oil products. Currently, the main adsorbents used include high specific surface area porous materials such as activated carbon, zeolite, silica, and MOFs. The disadvantage of ADS technology is that the selective adsorption capacity of sulfide is insufficient, the recovery of adsorbent is more complicated, and the recycling rate is not high. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) is usually achieved by using an oxidant to oxidize thiophene sulfides to corresponding sulfones or sulfoxides under the action of a catalyst, and then using distillation, adsorption, or polar solvent extraction methods to separate sulfones or sulfoxides, thereby achieving the goal of desulfurization [11–13]. In recent years, ODS technology has been regarded as the most promising green desulfurization technology in the 21st century due to its mild reaction conditions, high removal efficiency for thiophene sulfides, and no pollution [3,14,15]. Heteropoly acids (HPA) have been widely used in the fields of fine chemicals, petrochemicals, and catalysis due to their unique characteristics of strong acidity, strong oxidation, and pseudo liquid phase behavior [16]. Especially in the field of catalytic oxidation desulfurization, HPA catalysts have shown high catalytic activity towards thiophene sulfides. Currently, common Keggin type heteropolyacid catalysts in ODS reactions include H3PMo12O40 [17], H3PW12O40 [18], and H4SiW12O40 [19]. However, due to the presence of various fatty sulfur-containing compounds and thiophene sulfur-containing compounds in fuel, pure heteropolyacid catalysts also have insufficient desulfurization activity. In this case, by adjusting the type and number of heteroatoms and coordination atoms in heteropolyacids to prepare transition metal substituted heteropolyacids, their acidity and redox properties can be further enhanced, and the catalytic activity of heteropolyacids can be improved. Wei et al. [20] self-assembled a series of catalysts H3 through a one pot hydrothermal synthesis method H3+nPMo12-nVnO40@rht-MOF-1 (n = 1,2,3), the results of oxidative desulfurization showed that using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant, the removal rate of sulfide DBT was significantly affected by the increase of vanadium intake in heteropolyacid H3+nPMo12-nVnO40. The desulfurization rates of PMo11V1, PMo10V2, and PMo9V3 were 90 %, 92 %, and 96 %, respectively. However, due to its low surface area and easy solubility in polar solvents, HPA is limited in the field of catalytic desulfurization [21]. At present, the catalytic activity and cyclic performance of heteropolyacids are mainly improved by loading them onto materials with high specific surface area. Commonly used carriers include SiO2 [22], TiO2 [23], SBA-15 molecular sieve [24], and MOFs. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous crystalline materials formed by self-assembly of inorganic metal ions or metal clusters with organic ligands. Due to their high specific surface area, abundant porosity, and strong size controllability, MOFs have shown promising application prospects in energy storage, catalysis, and separation fields [25,26]. Especially in the field of catalytic oxidation desulfurization, MOFs with high specific surface area and nanocavities are often used to load active components such as heteropolyacids [27], metal nanoparticles [28], and ionic liquids [29], thus preparing loaded catalysts for ODS reactions. Gao et al. [4] obtained catalyst PW4@UIO-66-NH2/GO by loading peroxyphosphotungstate (PW4) onto composite material UIO-66-NH2/GO.ODS results demonstrated that the catalyst could remove 99.9 % of sulfides in the model fuel, and its activity did not significantly decrease after repeated use for 10 times. This is because the pore size and window size of UIO-66-NH2 effectively encapsulated the active component PW4, preventing its leaching during the reaction process. Therefore, the cavity size and window size of the MOF skeleton have a significant impact on the loading amount of heteropolyacids and the removal rate of sulfides. Firstly, if the MOF cavity is too large, it is easy to cause the aggregation of heteropolyacids after loading, thereby affecting their activity. Secondly, if the window size of the MOF is larger than the diameter of the heteropolyacid, it is easy to cause the loss of active components and reduce the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Finally, if the window size of the MOF is smaller than the diameter of the sulfide, the sulfide is less likely to enter the MOF cavity and react with heteropolyacids, thereby affecting the catalytic desulfurization performance of the catalyst [30–32]. As mentioned above, selecting MOFs with appropriate sizes to encapsulate active components is crucial for ODS reactions. Due to the poor thermal and chemical stability of MOFs materials in practical applications, if mesoporous silica (mSiO2) materials with higher stability are used as shells to coat the surface of MOFs, they can better provide protection and improve the stability of the core MOFs. Li et al. [33] used CTAC(CTAC=Cetyltrimethyl ammonium chloride) as a mesoporous template, and successfully coated mesoporous silica materials on the surface of MOFs using the traditional sol gel method. The atomic force microscope test found that the mechanical stability of MOFs was indeed significantly improved. In addition, the pore size of mSiO2 is larger than that of MOFs, and chemical reactants can easily penetrate this shell to reach the core phase without damaging the inherent properties of MOFs. Zhao et al. [34] introduced Pt nanoparticles between UiO-66-NH2 core and mSiO2 shell to obtain sandwich type catalysts UiO-66-NH2@Pt@mSiO2, the mSiO2 shell not only protects the MOF skeleton, but also effectively prevents the aggregation and leaching of Pt NPs during the reaction process, resulting in excellent catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst in subsequent catalytic reactions. On the basis of the above researches, this paper uses highly catalytic vanadium disubstituted phosphomolybdic acid H5PMo10V2O40 (PMoV2) as the desulfurization active component. Four MOFs (MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) with different cavity and window sizes are selected as carriers to encapsulate heteropolyacids. Finally, a layer of mesoporous silica (mSiO2) is coated on the surface of the MOFs to obtain four sandwich type catalysts 30 %PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) (Scheme 1). The morphology and structure of the designed catalyst were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, N2 adsorption desorption isotherms, SEM, TEM, etc. to verify the successful synthesis of the sandwich structure. The influence of different MOF window sizes of the four catalysts on the removal rate of four thiophene sulfides was investigated. The optimal catalyst was investigated for reaction temperature, stirring rate, catalyst dosage, oxygen sulfur ratio, and cyclic performance. A reasonable explanation was given for the mechanism of oxidative desulfurization. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Materials All reagents used in this work are analytical grade and purchased from China. Anhydrous ethanol (AR), methanol (AR), acetic acid (AR), hydrofluoric acid (AR), ammonia (AR), acetonitrile (CH3CN, AR), and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR) were all purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Acetone (AR) was purchased from Tianjin Lianlong Bohua Pharmaceutical Chemical Co., Ltd. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR), n-octane (C8H18, AR), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 wt%) all come from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Both concentrated sulfuric acid (AR) and ether (AR) were purchased from Sichuan Xilong Science Co., Ltd. Zirconium chloride (ZrCl4, ≥99.9 %), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 99 %), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, average molecular weight 58,000), 2-methylimidazole (C4H6N2, 98 %), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 98 %), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, AR), vanadium pentoxide (V2O5, 99.5 %), anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 99.5 %), sodium dihydrogen phosphate dodecahydrate (Na2HPO4·12H2O, AR) and sodium molybdate dihydrate (Na2MoO4·2H2O, AR) were both purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Six water and zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.95 %) was purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Nine hydrated chromium nitrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, 99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Yien Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (HO2CC6H4C6H4CO2H, 98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Sa'en Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. Hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAC, AR) was purchased from Mulan Town Industrial Development Zone, Xindu District, Chengdu City. The drugs used in the desulfurization experiment: benzothiophene (1-BT, 97 %), dibenzothiophene (DBT, 98 %), 4-methylbenzothiophene (4-MDBT, 96 %), 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT, 97 %), and n-hexadecane (AR) were all purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of PMoV2 The substituted Keggin type heteropolyacid H5PMo10V2O40 was prepared according to the method described by She et al. [35]. The specific synthesis steps are as follows: 1.5 mmol 0.537 g Na2HPO4·12H2O and 15.0 mmol 3.630 g Na2MoO4·2H2O were dissolved in 80 mL H2O. They were heated to 90 °C and reacted for 30 minutes. 1.875 mmol 0.341 g V2O5 was dissolved in 10 mL of 1.0 mol/L Na2CO3 solution and added to the above reacted solution. The mixture was continued to react for 30 minutes before. After the reaction temperature drops to room temperature, 1:1 diluted concentrated sulfuric acid was slowly added to the solution until the pH = 2.0.The mixture was placed in a separating funnel, 30 mL of ether and 1:1 diluted concentrated sulfuric acid were added, continued to be shaked, extracted multiple times, and let the funnel stand to separate the lower layer of bright red oily substance, which is the heteropoly acid ether complex. Heat and grind a small amount of oily substance onto a surface dish to obtain an orange yellow powder. After dried in an oven for 24 hours, heteropoly acid H5PMo10V2O40 was obtained and denoted as PMoV2. 2.2.2 Synthesis of MOF and 30%PMoV2@MOF (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) 2.2.2.1 Synthesis of MIL-101 and 30%PMoV2@MIL-101 The synthesis method of porous MIL-101 (Cr) material referred to reported research by Ribeiro et al. [36]. 0.400 g Cr(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.166 g H2BDCwere added to 10 mL of an aqueous solution containing 100 μL hydrofluoric acid. After the mixture was stirred for 5 minutes, transferred to a high-pressure reactor and placed it in a drying oven at 220 °C for a constant temperature reaction of 9 hours. After the reaction was completed, let the solution cool to room temperature and placed it in a centrifuge at 8000 r/min for 3 minutes to remove the incomplete reaction of 2-aminoterephthalic acid. The obtained product was washed and centrifuged twice with DMF and ethanol respectively, and dried at 80 °C to obtain green powder, namely MIL-101(Cr). The synthesis method of 30%PMoV2@MIL-101 is similar to MIL-101(Cr), except that 0.1731 g of PMoV2 was added while weighing Cr(NO3)3·9H2O and H2BDC. The final obtained dark green powder is 30%PMoV2@MIL-101. (The load capacity of PMoV2 is 30 %) 2.2.2.2 Synthesis of HKUST-1 and 30%PMoV2@HKUST-1 HKUST-1 crystals were synthesized using solution method [37]. Firstly, 0.15 g of Cu(NO3) 2·3H2O was dissolved in a mixed solvent containing 10 mL of EtOH and DMF (VEtOH: VDMF=1:1), denoted as solution A; Secondly, 0.52 g of H3BTC and 0.60 g of PVP were dissolved in a mixed solvent containing 20 mL of EtOH and DMF (VEtOH: VDMF=1:1), denoted as solution B (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O to H3BTC molar ratio of 1:4). Solution A was added to solution B while stirring, and placed it in a constant temperature water bath and stirred at 85 °C for 60 minutes. After the reacted, the product was washed three times by centrifugation with anhydrous ethanol to obtain a blue crystal, which is HKUST-1. The synthesis method of 30%PMoV2@HKUST-1 is similar to HKUST-1, except that 0.15 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O is dissolved in a mixed solvent containing EtOH and DMF, and 0.34 g of PMoV2 is added. The final dark blue powder obtained is 30%PMoV2@HKUST-1. 2.2.2.3 Synthesis of UiO-67 and 30%PMoV2@UiO-67 UiO-67 was synthesized using the hydrothermal synthesis method reported in references [38,39]. The specific steps are as follows: Take a beaker and add 60 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and 5.6 mL of acetic acid (the introduction of acetic acid can adjust the size and morphology of the carrier), then weigh 0.360 g of 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid and 0.268 g of ZrCl4 and add them to the above solution, stirring for 10 minutes. After stirring, pour the above solution into a 100 mL high-pressure reactor and react at 120 °C for 24 hours. After the reaction is completed, wait for the reactor to drop to room temperature and pour the solution inside into a centrifuge tube. Centrifuge at 5000 r/min for 5 minutes, pour out the supernatant, wash and centrifuge the substrate twice with DMF and ethanol, and then dry overnight at 80 °C in a vacuum drying oven. After drying, white powder, UiO-67, is obtained. The synthesis method of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67 is similar to UiO-67, except that 0.2691 g of PMoV2 was added while weighing 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid and ZrCl4. The final blue powder obtained is 30%PMoV2@UiO-67. 2.2.2.4 Synthesis of ZIF-8 and 30%PMoV2@ZIF-8 ZIF-8 nanoparticles were synthesized using the method proposed by Pan et al. [40]. Dissolve 3.286 g of 2-methylimidazole in 50 mL of methanol and stir at room temperature for 5 minutes until a homogeneous and stable solution is formed, denoted as solution C. Take another beaker and weigh 1.476 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, dissolve it in 50 mL of methanol, stir for 5 minutes until completely dissolved, and record it as solution D. Then add solution C to solution D, and immediately a white precipitate appears. Continue stirring at room temperature for 5 minutes. After stirring, separate the obtained white liquid by centrifugation at 8000 rpm, pour out the upper clear liquid, wash the obtained substrate three times with anhydrous ethanol centrifugation, and then dry it in a 60 °C oven for 24 hours. The resulting white powder is ZIF-8. The synthesis method of 30%PMoV2@ZIF-8 is similar to ZIF-8, except that 3.286 g of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in 50 mL of methanol while 1.311 g of PMoV2 was added. The final green powder obtained is 30%PMoV2@ZIF-8. 2.2.3 Synthesis of 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) catalyst According to the template method reported in references [33,39], an mSiO2 shell was coated on the surface of 30%PMoV2@MOF composite material. Add 100 mg 30%PMoV2@MOF (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) and 0.2 g CTAC were dissolved in a mixed solution containing 100 mL H2O and 20 mL ethanol, heated to 50 °C, and reacted for 1 hour. Then add 0.5 mL of ammonia to the solution and stir for 10 minutes. Add 10 mL of ethanol solution containing 0.40 mL of TEOS to the mixed solution within 6 hours, i.e. add 2 mL per hour. After the reaction, collect the product by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 minutes, wash repeatedly with anhydrous ethanol, and then dry overnight at 80 °C. In order to remove the soft template CTAC in the mSiO2 channel, the product was calcined in N2 flow (50.0 mL·min-1) at 250 °C for 7 hours to obtain a catalyst of 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8). 2.3 Characterization Record the FT-IR spectra of samples within the range of 4000–400 cm-1 on the Bruker Tensor-27 infrared spectrometer produced by the German company Brooke. Under voltage and current of 40 kV and 40 mA, the sample was analyzed using the Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer produced by the German company Bruker at a scanning speed of 0.1 °/min, with an angle range of 5–80° and an emission source of Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å). After degassing the sample under vacuum conditions of 393 K for 6 hours, nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis were performed on the sample using the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method using the TriStar II 3020 surface adsorption instrument produced by McMurray in the United States. The sample was sonicated and dispersed in anhydrous ethanol, then dropped onto a silicon wafer and dried overnight for scanning electron microscopy testing. The morphology of the sample was analyzed using Hitachi SU-8010 scanning electron microscope (SEM) produced by Hitachi in Japan. The morphology and elemental content of the samples were analyzed using the FEI Talos-F200X transmission electron microscope (TEM) produced by Thermo Fisher Scientific in the United States. The TEM preparation required dispersing the samples in anhydrous ethanol and drying them on a copper mesh for 12 hours. Under a nitrogen atmosphere, the sample was heated and analyzed using the STA 449A comprehensive thermal analyzer produced by German company NETZSCH at a rate of 5 °C/min. The concentration of sulfides was regularly measured using the GCMS-QP2010 gas chromatography-mass spectrometer produced by Shimadzu Instruments in Japan. N2 was used as the carrier gas for split injection, with a column box temperature of 200 °C, an injection port temperature of 200 °C, and a detector temperature of 250 °C. The analysis of the content of four thiophene sulfides under different reaction times was conducted using the TENSOR27 UV–vis spectrophotometer produced by Shimadzu Corporation in Japan. 2.4 ODS reaction process Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) requires weighing 129.5 mg of benzothiophene (BT), 175.9 mg of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 193.3 mg of 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), and 202.7 mg of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) in n-octane and diluting them to a 50 mL volumetric flask. Simulated fuel with a component concentration of 600 ppm and a total sulfur content of 2400 ppm is prepared. The UV visible spectrophotometer (UV–vis) analysis requires weighing the same amount of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT as mentioned above and diluting them in four 50 mL volumetric flasks to obtain four types of thiophene sulfides with sulfur content of 600 ppm in simulated fuel. The oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process, GC–MS analysis, and UV–vis analysis are the same as our previous work [41]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts MOF, 30%PMoV2@MOF, and 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) were tested and analyzed using an infrared spectrometer(Fig. 1 ). In Fig. 1a, the two strong absorption peaks at 1620.8 cm-1 and 1405.5 cm-1 in the infrared spectrum of MIL-101 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the O-C-O bond in the carboxylic acid group, and the characteristic absorption peak at 587.2 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of the Cr-O bond. The appearance of all characteristic peaks confirms the successful synthesis of MIL-101 [42]. The characteristic absorption peak of HKUST-1 at 731 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of the Cu-O bond, while the characteristic peaks at 1645.7 cm-1 and 1376.2 cm-1 are attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration and symmetric stretching vibration of the O=C-C bond [43]. The characteristic bands of UiO-67′s infrared spectrum at 1610.3 cm-1 and 1408.4 cm-1 are attributed to the O-C-O stretching vibration of the terephthalic acid ligand, and the characteristic bands at 750 cm-1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the Zr-O-Zr bond in tetragonal zirconia [44]. ZIF-8 exhibits a strong characteristic absorption peak in the range of 800–1600 cm-1, which is attributed to the stretching vibration in the imidazole ring plane of the 2-methylimidazole ligand. This indicates that the organic ligand participates in the reaction and successfully binds to the metal center Zn2+, resulting in the successful preparation of ZIF-8. In Fig. 1b, four Keggin type characteristic absorption peaks corresponding to heteropolyacids were observed in 30%PMoV2@MOF at 700–1100 cm-1, indicating the successful loading of heteropolyacids by MOFs. Fig. 1c shows the FT-IR spectra of four catalysts with 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2. The absorption peaks at 3432 cm-1, 1078 cm-1, and 459 cm-1 are attributed to the synthesis of mSiO2, and there were no infrared absorption peaks corresponding to the four MOFs, indicating that the four MOFs have been successfully encapsulated in the mSiO2 shell. After calcination in N2 atmosphere, the C-H bond vibration peak belonging to CTAC disappeared at 2900 cm-1. The absorption peak at 1645 cm-1 is attributed to the bending vibration of the H-O-H bond in water, which originates from the crystalline water carried by the heteropolyacid and the water molecules adsorbed by the catalyst. X-ray diffraction analysis was performed on MOF, 30%PMoV2@MOF, and 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8(Fig. 2 ). In Fig. 2a, the XRD spectra of pure MIL-101 exhibit characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 5.02 °, 5.74 °, 8.30 °, and 8.95 °, corresponding to the (511), (531), (822), and (911) crystal planes of MIL-101 (Cr), respectively. This is consistent with the results reported in reference [45], indicating the successful synthesis of MIL-101 (Cr). The appearance peaks of UiO-67 crystal at 2θ = 5.6 °, 6.8 °, and 17.1 ° corresponds to the characteristic diffraction peaks of crystal planes (222), (400), and (422), and the peak intensity is very high, indicating that the crystallinity of UiO-67 is very good. The HKUST-1 crystal exhibits strong characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 6.6 °, 9.4 °, 11.7 °, 13.5 °, and 19.1 °, which are consistent with the reported positions of characteristic peaks in the MOF material. The characteristic peaks at these angles correspond to the (002), (022), (222), (004), and (044) crystal faces, respectively, indicating the synthesis of high crystallinity HKUST-1 [46]. The six high-intensity diffraction peaks of the microporous crystal ZIF-8 at 2θ = 7.4 °, 10.5 °, 12.8 °, 14.8 °, and 16.55 ° correspond to the (011), (002), (112), (022), (013), and (222) crystal planes, respectively, which are completely consistent with the characteristic peaks of the ZIF-8 standard XRD spectrum, indicating the successful synthesis of high crystallinity ZIF-8 materials [47]. Fig. 2b shows composite material 30%PMoV2@MOF The XRD pattern suggests that compared with the MOF material before loading, the diffraction peak intensity only weakens, indicating that the introduction of heteropolyacids has not changed the crystal structure of the MOF. No characteristic diffraction peaks of heteropolyacid PMoV2 were observed, indicating that the heteropolyacid was successfully encapsulated in the MOF framework and had good dispersibility. As shown in Fig. 2c, after being coated with mSiO2, 30%PMoV2@MOF still exhibits four characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to MOFs, indicating that the crystal structure of MOFs is still intact. Four catalysts showed new broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 23°, corresponding to the introduction of mSiO2. No diffraction peak of PMoV2 was found, which may be due to the high dispersibility of heteropolyacids with extremely small particle sizes and the double-layer coating of MOF and mSiO2. In addition, due to the formation of mSiO2 shell blocking some X-rays, the XRD diffraction peak intensity corresponding to MOF is weakened. The N2 adsorption desorption results of MOF, 30%PMoV2@MOF, and 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF=MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) are shown in Fig. 3 and Table 1 . From Fig. 3a, it can be seen that the N2 adsorption desorption isotherms of the four MOFs all exhibit I-type isotherms without hysteresis loops, indicating that they all have a microporous structure. The specific surface area and pore volume data of MOFs were obtained through the BET equation, as shown in Table 1. All four MOF materials have high specific surface area and pore volume, which provides a guarantee for efficient loading of heteropoly acid PMoV2. From the curves of 30%PMoV2@HKUST-1 and 30%PMoV2@ZIF-8 in Fig. 3b, it can be observed that when the relative pressure P/P0 = 0–0.4, the N2 adsorption capacity rapidly increases, exhibiting Langmuir type adsorption isotherms, which belong to typical microporous adsorption. When P/P0 = 0.4∼0.9, the curve is typical and has a clear hysteresis loop, which is caused by the capillary condensation of mesoporous materials. This indicates that HKUST-1 and ZIF-8 both have microporous and mesoporous structures, and the existence of mesopores may be due to the stacking between MOF particles [48]. As shown in Table 1, after loading PMoV2, the specific surface area and pore volume of the four MOFs all showed varying degrees of reduction. This is owing to the blockage of pore channels caused by the encapsulation of heteropolyacids inside the MOF and their adhesion to the MOF surface. Fig. 3c shows the N2 adsorption desorption isotherms of four catalysts with 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2. The isotherm types of the four composite 30%PMoV2@MOF coated with mSiO2 are all I/IV-type isotherms with H1 type hysteresis loops, indicating that the introduction of mSiO2 leads to the coexistence of micropores and mesoporous structures of MOFs in the samples. The mesoporous channels ensure that thiophene sulfides can smoothly enter the catalyst and react with heteropolyacids. At the same time, the encapsulation of mSiO2 can provide higher specific surface area and porosity while protecting the MOF skeleton and heteropolyacids from being easily lost, further promoting the conversion of sulfur-containing compounds. From Table 1, it can be seen that the specific surface area and pore volume of the four catalysts have all decreased, which may be due to excessive TEOS during the coating process causing particle aggregation, thereby reducing the specific surface area. The specific surface area size is ranked as 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2>30%PMoV2@MIL-101@mSiO2>30%PMoV2@ZIF-8@mSiO2>30%PMoV2@HKUST-1@mSiO2. Fig. 4 (a-d) presents scanning electron microscopy images of four types of catalysts 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2, displaying 30%PMoV2@MOF Morphology after coating mesoporous silica. It can be seen that the particle morphology of the four catalysts has basically changed to spherical shape, with obvious agglomeration phenomenon, which may be caused by uneven stirring during the synthesis process or excessive intake of TEOS. The average particle sizes of the four catalysts 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) are 550 nm, 408 nm, 665 nm, and 180 nm, respectively. There are significant differences in the particle size of catalysts (a), (b), and (c), which are related to the coating thickness of mSiO2. In addition, the free small spheres on the surface of the catalyst are individually formed silica spheres. Fig. 4(e and f) show the SEM images of UiO-67 and 30%PMoV2@UiO-67. The octahedral morphology of UiO-67 is regular and uniform in size. This is due to the competition between acetic acid and 4,4-biphenyldicarboxylic acid after the addition of acetic acid, which inhibits the nucleation rate of the reaction between 4,4-biphenyldicarboxylic acid and Zr4+. The morphology of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67 differs significantly from that of the parent UiO-67. After loading PMoV2, the morphology changes to an ellipsoidal shape, possibly due to the excessive introduction of heteropolyacids, which cause the attachment of heteropolyacid particles to the surface of the MOF, and the connection between the grains is not conducive to mass transfer [49]. Fig. 5 shows the thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of UiO-67 (a), composite material 30%PMoV2@UiO-67 (b), and catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 (c). The weight loss of UiO-67 from 0 to 100 °C is due to the removal of adsorbed water, with a weight loss of 24.51 %. In stage b, the weight loss from 400 to 600 °C is due to the decomposition of the UiO-67 skeleton, with a weight loss of 20.24 %. The reasons for weight loss in the four stages of 30 %PMoV2@UiO-67 (b) and 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 (c) are basically the same, but the weight loss in each stage is different. Stage A is within 100 °C, mainly for the removal of physically adsorbed water; phase B is between 100–200 °C, and the thermogravimetric curve slowly decreases, mainly due to the removal of heteropoly acid crystallization water; the C stage is from 200 to 400 °C, mainly the decomposition of heteropoly acid PMoV2; the d stage is from 400 to 600 °C, and the sample quality sharply decreases. It is speculated that the MOF skeleton is damaged, and the weight loss of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67 and 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 is 14.33 % and 9.73 %, respectively. The small weight loss of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 is due to the protective effect of the mSiO2 coating on the MOF surface. After the temperature rises to 600 °C, the decreasing trend of the thermogravimetric curve significantly weakens, indicating that the thermal decomposition process of the sample is basically over. From the thermogravimetric curve, it can be fully reflected that PMoV2 has good thermal stability below 200 °C, and the structure of UiO-67 will not be damaged at 400 °C, which also shows that UiO-67 is suitable for some high-temperature reaction systems. Fig. 6 shows the TEM, EDX and elemental mapping of the catalyst PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2. As shown in Fig. (a) and Fig. (b), the PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst has an obvious coating structure, and the thickness of the mSiO2 shell is about 18 nm, and the coated shape still retains the octahedral structure of UiO-67 and the octahedron is more rounded. Fig. (d) to Fig. (k) show the mapping representation of the elements, the dense distribution of C, O and Zr elements proves the successful synthesis of UiO-67, and the presence of P, Mo and V elements proves the successful load of PMoV2, but the element distribution is scattered, which may be related to the load. Si and O elements have been successfully coated with mesoporous silica shells on the surface of UiO-67, and the construction of the shells is an indispensable part of the catalyst, which effectively solves the problem of improving the stability of MOFs and the adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Fig. (c) shows the EDX spectroscopy analysis of the catalyst, which further illustrates that the heteropolyacids were successfully loaded with PMoV2 and coated with mSiO2, and the content of Mo and V elements obtained was low due to the possible loss of PMoV2 during the loading and coating process. The XPS characterization of catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 is shown in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7a, the high-resolution full spectrum shows that 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 is composed of C, Zr, Si, O, P, Mo, and V elements. The binding energies of Fig. 7b and e at 284.9 eV and 531.3 eV are attributed to the C1s and O1s peaks, respectively. The binding energies of 183.3 eV and 180.8 eV in Fig. 7c are attributed to Zr 3d 3/2 and Zr 3d 5/2 peaks, respectively, indicating that UiO-67 has been successfully synthesized. The peak at 514.9 eV in the Si 2p energy spectrum (Fig. 7d) proves that mSiO2 has been successfully coated. In Fig. 7f, the binding energy at 133.1 eV is attributed to P 2p respectively. Fig. 7g shows the two peaks of W element Mo 3d 3/2 and Mo 3d 5/2 at 233.1 eV and 229.9 eV In addition, a peak of V2p appears at 514.9 eV in Fig. 7h; The appearance of energy spectral peaks of P, Mo and V elements proves that PMoV2 has been successfully introduced into MOF. 3.2 Oxidative desulfurization performance of catalysts 3.2.1 Optimal catalyst for oxidative desulfurization The oxidative desulfurization reaction was carried out at a temperature of 55 °C, n(O)/n(S) = 4, stirring rate of 400 rpm, and catalyst dosage of 2.0 g/L. Sampling was completed every 15 minutes, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . As the reaction time increases, the removal efficiency of the four catalysts 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2 (MOF = MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT also increases. The reaction equilibrium is reached at 60 minutes, and the removal rate of sulfides remains basically unchanged. Therefore, the reaction time is set to 60 minutes in the subsequent oxidation desulfurization reaction. The desulfurization activity order of the four catalysts is 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2> 30%PMoV2@MIL-101@mSiO2>30%PMoV2@ZIF-8@mSiO2>30%PMoV2@HKUST-1@mSiO2, and the total removal rates of thiophene sulfides are 64.01 %, 59.12 %, 57.90 %, and 54.27 %, respectively. The use of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst for catalytic oxidation desulfurization reaction has the best effect, with desulfurization efficiencies of 73.01 %, 67.79 %, 60.04 %, and 55.19 % for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT, respectively. The desulfurization activity order of the four sulfides is BT>DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT. 3.2.2 Impact of MOF window size on desulfurization efficiency Figs. 9 and 10 show the size of MOF materials, as well as the molecular size of thiophene sulfides and heteropolyacids [50–53]. The cavity sizes of the four MOFs synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis method are all larger than the PMoV2 molecular diameter (10 Å), indicating that all four MOF materials can encapsulate heteropolyacids in the MOF skeleton. However, due to the window size (11.7–16 Å) of MIL-101 being larger than the diameter of heteropolyacid molecules, this not only reduces the PMoV2 loading rate and affects the catalytic activity of the catalyst when preparing 30%PMoV2@MIL-101 composite materials, but also reduces the service life of the 30%PMoV2@MIL-101@mSiO2 catalyst and affects its cyclic performance. Although the window sizes of HKUST-1 and ZIF-8 (4.0 Å and 3.4 Å) can avoid the loss of heteropolyacids, their narrow window sizes hinder the entry of four thiophene sulfides into the MOF cage and the reaction with the active component PMoV2, thereby affecting the catalytic oxidation desulfurization performance of catalysts 30%PMoV2@HKUST-1@mSiO2 and 30%PMoV2@ZIF-8@mSiO2. Under this premise, UiO-67 material perfectly solves the above problems, with window size (8.0 Å) and cavity size (18.0 Å) providing sufficient space to encapsulate PMoV2, as well as ensuring that thiophene sulfides come into contact with active components to accelerate the ODS reaction rate and significantly improve the desulfurization performance of catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2. 3.2.3 Exploration of optimal reaction conditions for catalyst In order to investigate the effect of different reaction conditions on the removal performance of thiophene sulfides, the optimal catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 was investigated in the following ODS experiments, including reaction temperature, stirring rate, catalyst dosage, and oxygen sulfur ratio. The desulfurization results are shown in Fig. 11 . Firstly, the optimal reaction temperature for ODS was selected, with a reaction time of 60 minutes, a stirring rate of 400 rpm, a catalyst dosage of 2.0 g/L, and n (O)/n (S) of 4. The results are shown in Fig. 11a. When the reaction temperature is 45 °C, the removal efficiency of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT is 64.55 %, 57.04 %, 46.74 %, and 37.79 %, respectively. As the reaction temperature increases, the desulfurization efficiency of the catalyst also increases. This is because the increase in temperature is conducive to increasing the percentage of activated molecules, increasing the number of effective collisions between molecules, and thus increasing the reaction rate. When the reaction temperature reaches 60 °C, the increase in desulfurization efficiency of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 reaches its maximum, with removal efficiencies of 75.66 %, 73.63 %, 64.41 %, and 59.76 % for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT, respectively. When the reaction temperature continues to rise, the removal rates of the four thiophene sulfides remain basically unchanged. Therefore, based on practical applications, 60 °C is chosen as the optimal reaction temperature. Select stirring rates of 300 rpm, 400 rpm, 500 rpm, 600 rpm, and 700 rpm for desulfurization testing. The remaining reaction conditions are: reaction temperature of 60 °C, reaction time of 60 minutes, n(O)/n(S) = 4, catalyst dosage of 2.0 g/L, as shown in Fig. 11b. When the stirring rate is increased from 300 rpm to 500 rpm, the removal efficiency of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT also increases from 67.96 %, 64.33 %, 58.57 %, and 54.34 % to 83.57 %, 79.50 %, 71.74 %, and 65.69 %. This is because the increase in stirring rate promotes the contact between the catalyst and thiophene sulfides. Continuing to increase the stirring rate, the removal efficiency of the four thiophene sulfides slowed down. Therefore, 500 rpm was chosen as the optimal stirring rate. The catalyst dosage was the ratio of the amount of catalyst added in the oxidation desulfurization experiment to the simulated fuel quantity. The effects of five catalyst dosages on the oxidation desulfurization results were investigated under the conditions of reaction time of 60 minutes, reaction temperature of 60 °C, stirring rate of 500 rpm, and n(O)/n(S) = 4. The results are shown in Fig. 11c. The desulfurization efficiency of four thiophene sulfides increases with the increase of catalyst dosage. When the catalyst dosage increases to 2.5 g/L, the removal rates of the four sulfides by 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst increase to 88.84 %, 86.81 %, 76.67 %, and 72.23 %. Continuing to increase the catalyst dosage to 3.5 g/L, the desulfurization efficiency of the four thiophene sulfides did not increase significantly. Therefore, for economic and industrial applicability considerations, 2.5 g/L was chosen as the optimal catalyst dosage. The oxygen sulfur ratio (n(O)/n(S)) is the molar ratio of oxygen atoms in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to sulfur atoms in sulfides. The amount of hydrogen peroxide plays a crucial role in oxidative desulfurization experiments, so exploring the oxygen sulfur ratio is essential. Select n (O)/n (S) = 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 for desulfurization testing. The remaining reaction conditions are: reaction time of 60 minutes, reaction temperature of 60 °C, stirring rate of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, as shown in Fig. 11d. When n(O)/n(S) increases from 4 to 7, the removal efficiency of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 for BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT increases from 88.84 %, 86.81 %, 76.67 %, and 72.23 % to 98.61 %, 98.10 %, 87.01 %, and 82.39 %, respectively. At this time, the total removal rate of sulfides is 91.52 %. When n(O)/n(S) continues to increase, the desulfurization efficiency of the four thiophene sulfides is not significantly affected. Considering the issue of economic cost, the optimal n(O)/n(S) = 7 is selected. At this point, the optimal conditions for using 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst for oxidative desulfurization reaction have been obtained: reaction time of 60 minutes, reaction temperature of 60 °C, stirring rate of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, n(O)/n(S) = 7. 3.2.4 Ultraviolet absorption spectra of four thiophene sulfides after catalyst reaction at different times In order to confirm the high catalytic activity of catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2, UV absorption spectroscopy tests were conducted on the catalyst under optimal reaction conditions (reaction temperature of 60 °C, stirring rate of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, n(O)/n(S) = 7). The results are shown in Fig. 12 . Fig. 12a∼d show the UV absorption spectra of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT sulfides after different reaction times of catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2. The absorption peaks at 234 nm, 226 nm, 235 nm, and 236 nm in Fig. 12a∼d correspond to BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT sulfides, respectively. The larger the peak values of the absorption peaks of the four sulfur-containing compounds in the UV absorption spectrum, the higher the content of sulfur-containing compounds in the reaction system. As shown in Fig. 12a∼d, 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 was used as a catalyst for UV desulfurization testing. In the first 60 minutes, with the increase of reaction time, the content of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT sulfides significantly decreased. When the reaction lasted for 60 minutes, 97.86 % of BT, 93.49 % of DBT, 92.15 % of 4-MDBT, and 76.60 % of 4,6-DMDBT were oxidized into corresponding sulfone substances BTO2, DBTO2, 4-MDBTiO2, and 4,6-DMDBTO2 in the reaction system, respectively. The total removal rate of sulfides was 90.02 %, which is very close to the total desulfurization rate of 91.52 % measured by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS), once again proving the high catalytic activity of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2. When the reaction time exceeds 60 minutes, the absorption peaks of the four thiophene sulfides do not decrease significantly, indicating that the removal rate of sulfides has reached its maximum, which is consistent with the results of gas quality detection. 3.2.5 Cycle usability and stability testing of catalyst In order to investigate the stability and recyclability of catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2, cyclic tests were conducted on the catalyst under optimal reaction conditions (reaction time of 60 minutes, stirring rate of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, temperature of 60 °C, n(O)/n(S) = 7). As shown in Fig. 13 , the removal rates of four sulfides by the catalyst gradually decreased during 10 consecutive cycles. By the tenth cycle, the removal rates of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT by the catalyst decreased from 98.61 %, 98.10 %, 87.01 %, and 82.39 % to 93.63 %, 93.65 %, 80.17 %, and 77.52 %, respectively. The total desulfurization rate only decreased by 5.01 %, once again proving the excellent catalytic performance of the catalyst. The decrease in desulfurization rate may be due to the catalyst adsorbing a small amount of sulfur-containing compounds during cyclic use, which blocks the pores and leads to the leaching of a small amount of heteropoly acid 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2. According to the FT-IR (b) and XRD (c) diagrams of the catalyst before and after cycling, it can be seen that the catalyst has not changed, indicating its good stability. 3.2.6 Study on catalytic desulfurization performance of different catalysts and acetonitrile extraction desulfurization performance The desulfurization performance of UiO-67@mSiO2, 30%PMoV2@UiO-67, 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 and acetonitrile extraction (without catalyst added) was studied under optimal conditions (reaction time of 60 minutes, reaction temperature of 60 °C, stirring rate of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, n(O)/n(S) = 7). The results are shown in Fig. 14 . The desulfurization activity sequence between different catalysts is 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2> 30%PMoV2@UiO-67> UiO-67@mSiO2, which once again confirms the high catalytic performance of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalysts. In addition, the removal efficiency of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT by acetonitrile extraction reaction were 44.71 %, 45.10 %, 28.58 %, and 17.60 %, respectively, indicating that the removal efficiency of various thiophene sulfides by simple extraction desulfurization is not good. Table 2 compares the oxidation desulfurization efficiency of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst with the supported catalyst reported in references [54–62]. It can be found that the catalyst synthesized in this article can achieve very high desulfurization efficiency in a short period of time under the condition of basically the same total sulfur content, and the oxygen sulfur ratio and catalyst dosage are not high. While being environmentally friendly, it can also greatly save costs, proving that the industrial practicality of the catalyst is very high. 3.2.7 Exploration of the oxidation mechanism of catalyst Fig. 15 illustrates the ODS reaction mechanism of dibenzothiophene (DBT) on 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst. Firstly, DBT and H2O2 are adsorbed on the catalyst surface and enter the MOF cavity through mSiO2 pores and MOF windows. Then, the oxygen atoms in H2O2 attack the Mo=O and V=O nucleophilic groups of the [PMo10V2O40] [5]- anion to form the peroxidized phosphomolybdate vanadium anion. DBT is converted to sulfoxide DBTO under the attack of V(O2) or Mo(O2), and DBTO continues to react with the peroxidized phosphomolybdate vanadium anion to form sulfone DBTO2. After providing oxygen atoms, the peroxidized phosphomolybdate vanadium ion is reduced to phosphomolybdate vanadium ion and continues to participate in the next ODS reaction [56,63,64]. Finally, DBTO2 is extracted by the extractant acetonitrile to achieve the removal of sulfur-containing compounds from simulated oil. 4 Conclusion This article successfully synthesized Keggin type vanadium disubstituted heteropolyacid H5PMo10V2O40 (PMoV2), and encapsulated PMoV2 in four different window and cavity sizes of MOFs (MIL-101, ZIF-8, HKUST-1, UiO-67) using a one pot method. Finally, four sandwich type catalysts 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 were obtained by coating the MOF surface with mSiO2. The morphology and structure of four core-shell catalysts were characterized and they were used for catalytic oxidation desulfurization testing of four thiophene sulfides. The results demonstrate that catalyst 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 exhibits significant catalytic activity. Under the conditions of reaction time of 60 minutes, temperature of 60 °C, speed of 500 rpm, catalyst dosage of 2.5 g/L, and n(O)/n(S) = 7, the removal efficiencies of BT, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT are 98.61 %, 98.10 %, 87.01 %, and 82.39 %, respectively. This research has also found that the desulfurization activity of catalysts is related to the matching degree between the molecular size of thiophene sulfides and the MOF window. The MOF window size (8.0 Å) and cavity size (18.0 Å) of 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 catalyst provide sufficient space to encapsulate PMoV2, and also ensure that thiophene sulfides can smoothly enter the framework and react with the active components, thus exhibiting high desulfurization activity. The high desulfurization rate of the catalyst was also confirmed through UV desulfurization results. After 10 consecutive desulfurization experiments, it was found that the total desulfurization rate could still reach 86.24 %, and the original structure of the catalyst remained unchanged, indicating its excellent stability. coredata.dc:description: PMoV2 was encapsulated in four MOFs (MIL-101, HKUST-1, UiO-67, ZIF-8) with different cavity sizes and window sizes using a hydrothermal synthesis method. Then, a layer of mesoporous silica was coated on the surface of the MOFs to obtain four designed three-layer encapsulated catalysts 30%PMoV2@MOF@mSiO2. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized through various characterization methods, and the influence of different MOF window sizes of the four catalysts on the removal rate of four thiophene sulfides was investigated. The optimal reaction conditions were also explored for the optimal catalyst. The results indicate that under simulated fuel of 2400 ppm, 30%PMoV2@UiO-67@mSiO2 owns the highest catalytic activity. Under optimal conditions, the total removal rate of four thiophene compounds was 91.52 %, and after ten cycles, the efficiency could still reach 86.24 %. This is attributed to the sufficient cavity size of UiO-67, which provides assurance for the loading of PMoV2 and the large window size, making it possible for the smooth reaction between sulfides and PMoV2.
